author: xtqqczze
body:
# PR Summary

* Remove locks and replace with `Interlocked.Increment` and `Interlocked.Decrement` where possible.

Note: if overflow/underflow occurs, an exception will not be thrown, even if compiled in checked mode. `Debug.Assert` checks reverted as there is currently no checked build.

comments.author: xtqqczze
comments.body:
Documentation for [Interlocked.Increment(Int32)](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/system.threading.interlocked.increment) states: 

> This method handles an overflow condition by wrapping: if location = Int32.MaxValue, location + 1 = Int32.MinValue. No exception is thrown.

comments.author: xtqqczze
comments.body:
> Documentation for [Interlocked.Increment(Int32)](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/system.threading.interlocked.increment) states:
> 
> > This method handles an overflow condition by wrapping: if location = Int32.MaxValue, location + 1 = Int32.MinValue. No exception is thrown.

This is the same behaviour for the regular increment operator `++`, unless compiled in checked mode. So I will add some Debug.Asserts.

> This is the same behaviour for the regular increment operator `++`, unless compiled in checked mode. So I will add some Debug.Asserts.

It seems PowerShell debug build does not check for arithmetic overflow. So `Debug.Assert` is unnecessary as there is no change in behaviour.
